data.heading: Introduction
data.text: The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) Software Requirements Specification outlines the objectives, standards, and functional framework for a city-wide, sensor-driven waste and recycling solution.

attributesChanged.text: The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) Software Requirements Specification outlines the objectives, standards, and functional framework for a city-wide, sensor-driven waste and recycling solution in Kamloops.

children.heading: Document Purpose
children.text: This Software Requirements Specification (SRS) establishes the complete requirements for the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS), the product developed by The Junkers. The target audience includes software developers, project managers, client representatives, city administrators, collection workers, residents, maintainers, QA/testers, and documentation writers. Its purpose is to define detailed, traceable requirements based on the vision from Assignment 1 and extended through requirements in Assignment 2.

attributesChanged.text: This Software Requirements Specification (SRS) establishes the complete requirements for the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) – the product developed by The Junkers for the City of Kamloops. The target audience includes software developers, project managers, client representatives, city administrators, collection workers, residents, maintainers, QA/testers, and documentation writers. Its purpose is to define detailed, traceable requirements based on the vision from Assignment 1 and extended through requirements elicitation in Assignment 2.

children.heading: Document Conventions
children.text:
• Each requirement, objective, and risk in this document is assigned a unique identifier for traceability as per best SRS practices.
  • Use cases are prefixed UC-XX (e.g., UC-01).
  • High, Medium, or Low priority is noted in italics after each feature descriptor.
  • Terminology and abbreviations are defined in Section 9 (Glossary).
  • Tables or numbered paragraphs are used instead of unstructured lists for all formally referenced items.

attributesChanged.text:
• Each requirement, objective, and risk in this document is assigned a unique identifier for traceability (e.g., OBJ-01, REQ-10, RSK-05) as per best SRS practices.
  • Use cases are prefixed UC-XX (e.g., UC-01).
  • High, Medium, or Low priority is noted in italics after each feature descriptor.
  • All referenced documents follow IEEE citation guidelines.
  • Terminology and abbreviations are defined in Section 9 (Glossary).
  • Tables or numbered paragraphs are used instead of unstructured lists for all formally referenced items.

children.heading: Project Scope
children.text:
SWMRS is an integrated municipal software solution that will use IoT-enabled waste bin sensors, intelligent routing, mobile and web interfaces, and real-time analytics to enhance the efficiency of waste/recycling collection and community engagement. Major objectives include:

OBJ-01. Reduce operational expenditures by 20% in the first year through route optimization.

OBJ-02. Increase recycling rates by at least 30% by year-end via resident point-based gamification.

OBJ-03. Achieve a 15% reduction in missed collections through automated fill-level monitoring and alerts.

OBJ-04. Lower the city sanitation fleet’s carbon emissions by 10% by minimizing unnecessary travel.

The scope and business context are established in the Vision & Scope Document (VSD), with this SRS focusing on requirements for the initial release of the SWMRS.

attributesChanged.text:
SWMRS is an integrated municipal software solution that will use IoT-enabled waste bin sensors, intelligent routing, mobile and web interfaces, and real-time analytics to enhance the efficiency of waste/recycling collection and community engagement in Kamloops. Major objectives include:

OBJ-01. Reduce operational expenditures by 20% in the first year through route optimization.

OBJ-02. Increase recycling rates by at least 30% by year-end via resident point-based gamification.

OBJ-03. Achieve a 15% reduction in missed collections through automated fill-level monitoring and alerts.

OBJ-04. Lower the city sanitation fleet’s carbon emissions by 10% by minimizing unnecessary travel.

The scope and business context are established in the Vision & Scope Document (VSD), with this SRS focusing on requirements for the initial release of the SWMRS.

data.heading: Overall Description
data.text: This section provides a high-level overview of the SWMRS, its users, the primary operating environment, major constraints, and foundational project assumptions.

children.heading: Product Perspective
children.text: SWMRS is a newly designed, city-wide, data-driven SaaS platform intended to replace the legacy manual and partially-digital waste management processes. It is architected to interact with decentralized IoT smart bins, municipal and contractor staff, resident users (via mobile/web), and a rewards vendor network. The SWMRS is the hub for data collection, monitoring, routing optimization, reward calculation, and cross-stakeholder communication.

attributesChanged.text: SWMRS is a newly designed, city-wide, data-driven SaaS platform intended to replace Kamloops’ legacy manual and partially-digital waste management processes. It is architected to interact with decentralized IoT smart bins, municipal and contractor staff, resident users (via mobile/web), and a rewards vendor network. The SWMRS is the hub for data collection, monitoring, routing optimization, reward calculation, and cross-stakeholder communication.

children.heading: User Classes and Characteristics
children.text:
User Class​​​​​TypeDescriptionFavourability

Favoured

Favoured

Favoured

Favoured
Data AttackerIndirectThreatens system security (handled via security systems)
Unfavored
Unauthorized UserDirect
Attempts system breach or unauthorized actions
Unfavored

children.heading: Use Cases and Models
children.text:
The primary use cases for SWMRS are as follows:

UC-01. Optimize Collection Route

UC-02. Report Missed Pickup/Issue

UC-03. Resident Track Recycling Rewards

UC-04. Worker Pickup Confirmation

UC-05. City Admin Monitor Fleet/Sensor Dashboard

UC-06. Supervisor Manage Exceptions (approve/reject)

UC-07. Sensor Health and Alerts

UC-08. Manage Rewards Catalog

Model diagrams (use case, context, and activity) are provided in the assignment appendix.

children.heading: Operating Environment
children.text:
• Mobile platforms: Android 12.0+ and iOS 16.0+ for both resident and worker apps.
  • Backend: Municipally managed secure servers (Windows Server 2019+ or Linux 22.04+), or cloud-based (Azure/GCP).
  • IoT modules: LoRaWAN/Zigbee/3G/4G integration for bin telemetry.
  • APIs: RESTful endpoints for traffic/weather integration and third-party rewards partners.
  • City office web portals deployed on secure municipal intranet.

children.heading: Design and Implementation Constraints
children.text:
• Comply with City and Province privacy/security policy.
  • Integration limited to officially certified IoT sensor vendors.
  • Mobile applications must function in offline mode with eventual data sync for workers.
  • All interfaces WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessible.
  • Open, documented APIs only; no legacy, proprietary, or closed-source dependencies in the first release.

attributesChanged.text:
• Comply with City of Kamloops and BC privacy/security policy.
  • Integration limited to officially certified IoT sensor vendors.
  • Mobile applications must function in offline mode with eventual data sync for workers.
  • All interfaces WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessible.
  • Open, documented APIs only; no legacy, proprietary, or closed-source dependencies in the first release.

children.heading: Assumptions and Dependencies
children.text:
• Sufficient mobile device and connectivity coverage for field staff and residents.
  • Regular calibration/maintenance of deployed sensor units.
  • Stable partnerships with rewards vendors.
  • Staff will be trained in mobile/web platforms.
  • Timely third-party API responses for route optimization.
  • Future expansion to other municipalities or language markets will be a separate scope.

data.heading: System Features
data.text: This section identifies and details the core functional features that form the backbone of the SWMRS platform. Each feature is presented with a concise summary, priority ranking, and a set of traceable requirements to support effective implementation and system validation.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Dynamically generates and updates optimized collection routes for workers, leveraging real-time sensor data, traffic conditions, and administrator settings. Minimizes operational costs and reduces missed or late pickups.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Worker launches mobile app at start of shift → System downloads current optimal route (SRQ-01).
  • Bin sensor reports fill level ≥ threshold during route → System recalculates and adjusts route, notifies worker in-app (SRQ-02).
  • Worker enters area with poor connectivity → App switches to offline cached route, syncs updates when reconnected (SRQ-03).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-001System shall use real-time bin sensor data to calculate optimal pickup order.
REQ-002
System must integrate live traffic data from external APIs when proposing a route.
REQ-003
Workers using the mobile app must be able to download and view their daily route with map support.
REQ-004
Application must support offline access for routes, with data syncing after connectivity returns.
REQ-005
Route changes must be logged and auditable by supervisors.
REQ-006
Worker must receive in-app notifications for urgent reroutes or bin status changes en route.
REQ-007
System must record all completed pickups along with timestamps and GPS location.
REQ-008
Administrator must be able to define/adjust routing rules and thresholds.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Enables IoT-enabled bins to continuously monitor and report fill levels, contamination, and obstructions to the SWMRS server for status tracking, operational decisions, and auditability.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Bin sensor transmits fill level, contamination, and status data every 10 minutes → System updates bin status in dashboard (SRQ-04).
  • Unusual sensor reading (e.g., >100% full, no data for 24h) → System alerts maintenance technician and disables bin from routing until resolved (SRQ-05).

attributesChanged.text: Priority: High

Priority: High

Enables IoT-enabled bins to continuously monitor and report fill levels, contamination, and obstructions to the SWMRS server for status tracking, operational decisions, and auditability.

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-009Each bin must report fill level, contamination, and access status to the server at least every 10 min.
REQ-010
Sensor data shall be transferred using encrypted protocols.
REQ-011
System must flag any bin not reporting data for over 24 hours.
REQ-012
Sensor anomalies (impossible data, eg. >150%) are to be auto-flagged and excluded from routing.
REQ-013
Technician must receive maintenance alert for flagged bins.
REQ-014
All bin status data must be retained and auditable for at least 2 years.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Allows residents to track their collection schedules, receive proactive notifications, report missed pickups/issues, and view participation/rewards via a secure, intuitive mobile app.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Resident opens app to check schedule → System displays bin status, next scheduled pickup, and remaining days (SRQ-06).
  • Resident receives notification (“Pickup tomorrow”, “Pickup complete”, or “Skipped: contamination”) (SRQ-07).
  • Resident identifies a missed pickup and submits an issue report with description and photo; system logs event and notifies supervisor (SRQ-08).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-015Mobile app must display personalized collection day and history using geolocation and bin ID.
REQ-016
App must deliver push notifications for upcoming and completed pickups, and skip explanations.
REQ-017
Residents must be able to submit skipped pickup/issue reports with geotagged photo and text.
REQ-018
Complaint/issue reports must generate case numbers trackable by both resident and supervisor.
REQ-019
Residents shall view their recycling score, total points, and rewards catalog in-app.
REQ-020
App must comply with accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1 AA).

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: Medium

Implements a transparent points-based program tracking resident recycling via unique bin IDs and enables redemption of points in a reward catalog sponsored by local businesses.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response
children.text:
• Bin is collected and weighed, or recycling event logged → System credits resident’s reward points based on grade and volume (SRQ-09).
  • Resident redeems points for a local business voucher → System issues voucher code or QR, updates points tally (SRQ-10).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-021System must track recycling score/history per resident-linked bin.
REQ-022
Points must be calculated and added in real time after successful recycling pickups.
REQ-023
Residents must be able to view, browse, and redeem from the up-to-date rewards catalog in the app.
REQ-024
Redemption events must trigger notification to both resident and business sponsor.
REQ-025
All redemption and earning data must be retained for at least two years.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Provides city administrators and supervisors a comprehensive dashboard that displays real-time truck status, route progress, missed pickups, fuel usage, compliance analytics, and system warnings for proactive operational management.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Administrator logs in to dashboard → System displays fleet map, truck/bins status, active alerts (SRQ-11).
  • Analytics module triggers urgent alert for 90% full bins or missed pickups → System enables quick re-routing or dispatch action (SRQ-12).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-026Dashboard must provide real-time status of all trucks, assets, and monitored bins.
REQ-027
Must display live route changes and allow filtering by status, region, or event type.
REQ-028
Enable administrators to adjust optimization parameters (fill threshold, zone priorities, etc.).
REQ-029
System must generate downloadable reports on performance and compliance with selectable filters.
REQ-030
Issue urgent alerts for high fill bins and sensor failures, integrating override options.

REQ-029

REQ-030

data.heading: Data Requirements
data.text: This section describes all data objects and models processed or generated by SWMRS, as well as requirements related to acquisition, protection, retention, and deletion. It is written to ensure that data is both usable and auditable, meeting city standards and privacy policies.

children.heading: Logical Data Model
children.text:
The SWMRS maintains relational data for waste bins, users, events, vehicles, reports, and rewards. The following high-level entities are modeled:

  • Bin (BinID, Location, FillLevel, ContaminationStatus, LastServiceDate, SensorHealth)
  • Resident (ResidentID, Address, LinkedBinID, RecyclingScore, RewardPoints, ContactInfo)
  • Worker (WorkerID, Name, AssignedRouteID, VehicleID)
  • Truck (TruckID, Registration, GPSLocation, FuelUsage, MaintenanceStatus)
  • CollectionEvent (EventID, TruckID, BinID, Timestamp, PickupConfirmed)
  • Complaint (ComplaintID, ResidentID, BinID, Type, PhotoURL, Status, ResolutionDate)
  • Reward (RewardID, PartnerID, Description, PointsRequired, DateRedeemed)
  • Supervisor (SupervisorID, Name, Role, ApprovalActions)
  • Partner (PartnerID, Name, VoucherFormat, RedemptionURL)

The relationships between these entities are shown in an ER diagram included in the appendices and referenced for database implementation.

children.heading: Data Dictionary
children.text:
Each important data structure is defined with allowed types and formats for validation and consistency:

BinIDString12AlphanumericUnique, A-Z 0-9Smart Waste Bin ID

Unique

n/aPositiveNeeded for redemption
GPSLocationString32Decimal, commaLat/LongTruck/route geotag

Additional details for rarely used fields are maintained in the system’s central data dictionary and regularly updated as requirements evolve.

children.heading: Reports
children.text:
The SWMRS supports standardized, filterable reports for city administration and auditing:

  1. Daily Operational Report: Tracks all pickups, missed pickups, route adjustments, and fleet/location status.
  2. Missed Pickup and Complaint Summary: Aggregates issues by cause (contamination, missed, obstruction), resolution status, and time to close.
  3. Sensor Health & Maintenance Alerts: Flags bins with abnormal readings or failed transmissions.
  4. Resident Recycling and Rewards Report: Summarizes points earned, redeemed, pending, and expired per resident.
  5. Compliance and Performance Audit: Details number of manual/automated route changes, fuel usage, emissions reduction, and service level metrics.

All reports are exportable in PDF and CSV formats with configurable date ranges and field selection.

attributesChanged.text:
The SWMRS supports standardized, filterable reports for city administration and auditing:

  1. Daily Operational Report: Tracks all pickups, missed pickups, route adjustments, and fleet/location status.
  2. Missed Pickup and Complaint Summary: Aggregates issues by cause (contamination, missed, obstruction), resolution status, and time to close.
  3. Sensor Health & Maintenance Alerts: Flags bins with abnormal readings or failed transmissions.
  4. Resident Recycling and Rewards Report: Summarizes points earned, redeemed, pending, and expired per resident.
  5. Compliance and Performance Audit: Details number of manual/automated route changes, fuel usage, emissions reduction, and service level metrics.

All reports are exportable in PDF and CSV formats with configurable date ranges and field selection.

children.heading: Data Acquisition, Integrity, Retention, and Disposal
children.text:
Acquisition

  • Bin sensors transmit data every ten minutes using encrypted RESTful service calls.
  • Mobile apps upload event, complaint, and confirmation data live, or cache offline with auto-sync on reconnect.

Integrity

  • Real-time validation of incoming fill levels and complaint data.
  • All route changes, pickups, and issue reports are logged with immutable timestamps.
  • Data backups performed daily with automated integrity verification scripts.

Retention and Disposal

  • All operational data is retained for a minimum of five years according to municipal rules.
  • Complaint and reward redemption records are kept for two years after resolution/redeeming unless flagged for audit.
  • Data flagged for deletion (resident closed account, resolved complaint) is securely removed after retention period.
  • Temporary/cache/offline data on devices is wiped after successful sync.

<If relevant, describe how data is acquired and maintained. State any requirements regarding the need to protect the integrity of the system's data. Identify any specific techniques that are necessary, such as backups, checkpointing, mirroring, or data accuracy verification. State policies the system must enforce for either retaining or disposing of data, including temporary data, metadata, residual data (such as deleted records), cached data, local copies, archives, and interim backups.>

data.heading: External Interface Requirements
data.text: This section describes the interfaces through which users, external software, hardware elements, and communications protocols interact with SWMRS. Each interface is specified for usability, interoperability, and compliance with city standards.

children.heading: User Interfaces
children.text:
SWMRS provides user interfaces for residents, collection workers, administrators, supervisors, and partners:

  • Resident Mobile App UI
    • Platforms: Android 12+, iOS 16+
    • Features: Personalized collection calendar, notification center, rewards dashboard, issue reporting form
    • Style: Complies with City accessibility guidelines (WCAG 2.1 AA), supports text enlargement, contrast adjustment, screen reader compatibility
    • UI elements: Standard navigation bar, home dashboard, actionable notifications, error messages with clear explanations
  • Worker Mobile App UI
    • Route map view (GPS-linked), bin status sidebar, pickup confirmation prompt, offline mode indicator
    • Embedded camera/photo upload for reporting issues
  • Administrator Web Dashboard
    • Secure login; real-time fleet map; route editor; filterable performance reports; analytics widgets
    • Customizable alert panel; system-wide audit history
  • Supervisor/Technician Portal
    • Quick-approve/reject issue dashboard, flagged sensor alerts, maintenance request forms

Standard icon sets, consistent button placements, keyboard shortcuts for frequent actions, and error messaging protocols are used throughout all interfaces.

children.heading: Software Interfaces
children.text:
SWMRS interacts with several external and city-hosted systems via secure APIs and data channels:

  • IoT Sensor Integration
    • RESTful endpoints accept periodic bin status updates from LoRaWAN/Zigbee modules
    • JSON-formatted POST requests; encrypted payloads
  • Traffic & Weather API
    • Real-time traffic conditions (e.g., Google Maps API, BC Ministry feeds) integrated for route optimization
    • Secure OAuth2 authentication; fallback to cached routes if unavailable
  • Partner Rewards API
    • HTTPS calls for point redemption, reward catalog updates, voucher status tracking
  • City Legacy Database Interface
    • Migrates scheduled pick-up and resident address data via bulk ETL jobs
    • Standardized CSV/XLSX formatting; integrity check on import
  • Authentication/Authorization
    • Uses OAuth2 for user login; RBAC enforced by backend middleware

Each software interface’s message schemas and protocols are documented in a separate technical reference.

attributesChanged.text:
SWMRS interacts with several external and city-hosted systems via secure APIs and data channels:

•IoT Sensor Integration

•RESTful endpoints accept periodic bin status updates from LoRaWAN/Zigbee modules

•JSON-formatted POST requests; encrypted payloads

•Traffic & Weather API

•Real-time traffic conditions (e.g., Google Maps API, BC Ministry feeds) integrated for route optimization

•Secure OAuth2 authentication; fallback to cached routes if unavailable

•Partner Rewards API

•HTTPS calls for point redemption, reward catalog updates, voucher status tracking

•City Legacy Database Interface

•Migrates scheduled pick-up and resident address data via bulk ETL jobs

•Standardized CSV/XLSX formatting; integrity check on import

•Authentication/Authorization

•Uses OAuth2 for user login; RBAC enforced by backend middleware

Each software interface’s message schemas and protocols are documented in a separate technical reference.

children.heading: Hardware Interfaces
children.text:
SWMRS hardware connections include:

  • Smart Waste Bin Sensors
    • Compatible with industry LoRaWAN and Zigbee wireless modules
    • Data: FillLevel (float), Status (enum), BatteryLevel (int), Timestamp (datetime)
  • GPS-Enabled Collection Vehicles
    • Receives route data, reports live location (lat/long), vehicle status, and odometer/fuel readings
    • USB/Bluetooth supported for in-vehicle tablets
  • Mobile Devices
    • Supported: Android (12+), iOS (16+), city-issued tablets/phones registered for SWMRS app deployments
  • Workstation Terminals
    • Administrators log into dashboard via browser extensions, local network, or VPN-secured remote access

All connections use encrypted wireless standards and follow city’s IT security architecture.

All connections use encrypted wireless standards and follow city’s IT security architecture.

children.heading: Communications Interfaces
children.text:
SWMRS supports secure, multi-modal communication for data transmission and notifications:

  • Network Protocols
    • All data is transmitted over HTTPS/TLS for privacy and security
    • Mobile apps auto-switch from WiFi to cellular if needed, with offline caching
  • Push Notifications
    • Real-time notifications for residents and workers delivered via Firebase/APNs for respective OS; queued if offline
  • Email Alerts
    • Exception reports, urgent compliance notifications, and regular summaries can be delivered to authorized recipients via SMTP plugin
  • Synchronization/Backup
    • Scheduled and event-triggered sync with servers; checkpoint markers for each transaction
  • Security & Encryption
    • All communications are subject to role-privilege filtering; audit logs capture sender/recipient/action for legal compliance

Any handling of third-party data follows the City legal and technical standards for encryption and retention.

data.heading: Quality Attributes
data.text: This section outlines the main product qualities and system-level non-functional requirements for SWMRS, specifying measurable standards for proficiency, robustness, compliance, and stakeholder satisfaction. Each quality attribute is labeled for traceability, audit, and clarity.

children.heading: Usability
children.text:
• QA-01: All major user interfaces must permit a new user (worker, resident, admin) to perform their core tasks within one hour of onboarding.
  • QA-02: The resident and worker mobile apps must comply with WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility standards, supporting screen readers, adjustable text sizes, and high-contrast themes.
  • QA-03: Error messages and instructions must be clear, context-specific, and provide actionable next steps.
  • QA-04: All interactive actions (e.g., reporting, route confirmation) should require no more than three taps/clicks from the main dashboard.

children.heading: Performance
children.text:
• QA-05: Mobile apps must load dashboards, routes, and schedules within two seconds of launch under normal conditions.
  • QA-06: Route recalculation on trigger (e.g., bin overflow, missed pickup alert) must complete in under five seconds.
  • QA-07: Backend synchronization after offline operation should complete within two minutes when connectivity is restored.
  • QA-08: Data backups are performed daily, with each backup verified in under one hour.

children.heading: Security
children.text:
• QA-09: All resident, worker, and administrator accounts must use secure, role-based access controls enforced by OAuth2 and backend middleware.
  • QA-10: All data at rest and in transit must be encrypted using at least AES-256/TLS 1.2.
  • QA-11: System must log and audit all sensitive changes (routes, sensor status, complaints, redemptions) with timestamps and user authentication details.
  • QA-12: SWMRS must comply with municipal and provincial privacy legislation regarding resident data handling and retention.

children.heading: Safety
children.text:
• QA-13: Every collection vehicle must pass a digital pre-trip safety checklist before any route is activated; any failed checklist locks out the worker app and sends an alert to supervisors.
  • QA-14: Bin sensor anomalies, dangerous contamination, or obstructions detected during route planning must trigger an immediate alert, excluding affected bins from live operational data until resolved.
  • QA-15: Residents and workers reporting hazardous events (contamination, obstruction) should be presented with safety information immediately, both on app and via automated notification.

children.heading: Reliability
children.text:
• QA-16: System uptime must meet or exceed 99.9% (measured monthly).
  • QA-17: SWMRS must avoid data loss on mobile or backend, backing up all synchronized records and providing error logs for manual review.
  • QA-18: Automated health checks run hourly for all sensors, APIs, and fleet dashboards, with email/SMS alerts on failure.

children.heading: Other Attributes
children.text:
• Scalability (QA-19): Backend infrastructure must support up to twice projected city user/device load for three years post-launch, with elastic cloud expansion available.
  • Interoperability (QA-20): All third-party integrations must use open, documented standards, with connector modules tested quarterly for compatibility.
  • Maintainability (QA-21): Modular codebase with well-documented interfaces required; critical bugs are resolved within three business days of identification.
  • Auditability (QA-22): All major actions and changes are logged with full traceability for compliance and stakeholder review.

attributesChanged.text:
• Scalability (QA-19): Backend infrastructure must support up to twice projected Kamloops user/device load for three years post-launch, with elastic cloud expansion available.
  • Interoperability (QA-20): All third-party integrations must use open, documented standards, with connector modules tested quarterly for compatibility.
  • Maintainability (QA-21): Modular codebase with well-documented interfaces required; critical bugs are resolved within three business days of identification.
  • Auditability (QA-22): All major actions and changes are logged with full traceability for compliance and stakeholder review.

data.heading: Internationalization and Localization Requirements
data.text:
This section addresses the internationalization and localization needs of SWMRS, ensuring usability, compliance, and cultural accessibility for all supported user groups.

  • IL-01: The SWMRS resident and worker mobile apps, along with the administrator dashboard, must support both English and French for all end-user content, UI labels, help documentation, and system notifications, in compliance with Canadian federal and provincial requirements.
  • IL-02: All date and time fields are displayed according to the local timezone of the user, with support for daylight saving adjustments where applicable.
  • IL-03: Numeric fields (such as fill levels, points, or bin volumes) must support comma and period as decimal separators, determined by system language settings.
  • IL-04: All addresses, phone numbers, and postal codes must be stored and rendered using Canadian formats, with support for province/territory selection and validation; internationalization is planned in future versions.
  • IL-05: Paper size defaults, sorting order, and printable reports should conform to Canadian standards (A4, ascending alphabetical, etc.) but be configurable per locale.
  • IL-06: Units of measurement (e.g., weight, volume) in the system are shown in metric by default but can be switched to imperial (pounds, gallons) by user or organization preference.
  • IL-07: All system messages, error texts, and customer support templates must be translatable strings (no hard-coded language), supporting future extension to other languages.
  • IL-08: System must accommodate left-to-right and right-to-left layouts in anticipation of further localization (design constraints documented, although not required for initial release).
  • IL-09: Currency fields (e.g., for business rewards or vouchers) default to CAD but are stored with ISO 4217 currency codes and formatted according to locale.

attributesChanged.text:
This section addresses the internationalization and localization needs of SWMRS, ensuring usability, compliance, and cultural accessibility for all supported user groups.

IL-01: The SWMRS resident and worker mobile apps, along with the administrator dashboard, must support both English and French for all end-user content, UI labels, help documentation, and system notifications, in compliance with Canadian federal and provincial requirements.

IL-02: All date and time fields are displayed according to the local timezone of the user, with support for daylight saving adjustments where applicable.

IL-03: Numeric fields (such as fill levels, points, or bin volumes) must support comma and period as decimal separators, determined by system language settings.

IL-04: All addresses, phone numbers, and postal codes must be stored and rendered using Canadian formats, with support for province/territory selection and validation; internationalization is planned in future versions.

IL-05: Paper size defaults, sorting order, and printable reports should conform to Canadian standards (A4, ascending alphabetical, etc.) but be configurable per locale.

IL-06: Units of measurement (e.g., weight, volume) in the system are shown in metric by default but can be switched to imperial (pounds, gallons) by user or organization preference.

IL-07: All system messages, error texts, and customer support templates must be translatable strings (no hard-coded language), supporting future extension to other languages.

IL-08: System must accommodate left-to-right and right-to-left layouts in anticipation of further localization (design constraints documented, although not required for initial release).

IL-09: Currency fields (e.g., for business rewards or vouchers) default to CAD but are stored with ISO 4217 currency codes and formatted according to locale.

data.heading: Other Requirements
data.text:
This section specifies requirements for legal compliance, product deployment, operational processes, and system monitoring, supplementing previous feature and quality specifications.

  • OR-01: SWMRS must comply fully with all City & Province privacy regulations, including the Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA) and municipal waste handling statutes.
  • OR-02: All system logging, monitoring, and audit trails must be active by default and retained for at least five years, accessible by authorized personnel for regulatory review and incident investigation.
  • OR-03: Product installation scripts must automate deployment for both the backend (Windows/Linux servers) and mobile clients (Android/iOS), including company device onboarding and configuration.
  • OR-04: Configuration management procedures must be documented and support rollback for all major software updates; schema migrations must be handled in a controlled, traceable manner.
  • OR-05: System startup and shutdown must be logged, monitored, and capable of full error logging and recovery; all intentional restarts require supervisor notification.
  • OR-06: All data exports (reports, backups) must conform to city cybersecurity standards, using encrypted formats and secure transmission for all sensitive data.
  • OR-07: SWMRS must provide interfaces for authorized city IT staff to monitor health, usage, system events, and to trigger emergency shutdown in case of security violation or hardware failure.
  • OR-08: Incident response procedures and disaster recovery plans must be established for all core data and service components as part of site delivery.

attributesChanged.text:
This section specifies requirements for legal compliance, product deployment, operational processes, and system monitoring, supplementing previous feature and quality specifications.

  • OR-01: SWMRS must comply fully with all City of Kamloops and British Columbia privacy regulations, including the Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA) and municipal waste handling statutes.
  • OR-02: All system logging, monitoring, and audit trails must be active by default and retained for at least five years, accessible by authorized personnel for regulatory review and incident investigation.
  • OR-03: Product installation scripts must automate deployment for both the backend (Windows/Linux servers) and mobile clients (Android/iOS), including company device onboarding and configuration.
  • OR-04: Configuration management procedures must be documented and support rollback for all major software updates; schema migrations must be handled in a controlled, traceable manner.
  • OR-05: System startup and shutdown must be logged, monitored, and capable of full error logging and recovery; all intentional restarts require supervisor notification.
  • OR-06: All data exports (reports, backups) must conform to city cybersecurity standards, using encrypted formats and secure transmission for all sensitive data.
  • OR-07: SWMRS must provide interfaces for authorized city IT staff to monitor health, usage, system events, and to trigger emergency shutdown in case of security violation or hardware failure.
  • OR-08: Incident response procedures and disaster recovery plans must be established for all core data and service components as part of site delivery.

data.heading: Glossary
data.text:
Term/AcronymDefinition
SWMRSSmart Waste Management & Recycling System—project name for City's municipal waste/recycling app
BinIDUnique identifier assigned to each smart waste or recycling bin (alphanumeric, 12 chars)
IoTInternet of Things—network-connected physical devices reporting real-world conditions
GPSGlobal Positioning System—satellite-based system for providing live location information
WCAG 2.1 AAWeb Content Accessibility Guidelines, Level AA—standards for accessible digital interfaces
ResidentAny individual or household account using municipal waste/recycling services
SupervisorStaff with authority to review/approve exceptions, handle complaints, and manage operations
Collection WorkerMunicipal or contractor employee performing bin pickup and reporting tasks
AdministratorCity or contracted personnel managing routes, performance, system settings via SWMRS dashboardStaff with authority to review/approve exceptions, handle complaints, and manage operations
TechnicianStaff responsible for installing/repairing sensors and maintaining hardware
PartnerThird-party business participating in the rewards/voucher system
OAuth2Open Standard for secure authentication and authorization via token-based control
LoRaWAN/Zigbee
Industry-standard wireless protocols for IoT sensor communication
RBACRole-Based Access Control—user permissions model based on assigned roles
APIApplication Programming Interface—standard set of protocols for software or device communication
CSV/XLSXCommonly used tabular data file formats (Comma-Separated Values, Excel)
PIPAPersonal Information Protection Act—BC privacy law regarding handling of personal information
ETLExtract, Transform, Load—process for migrating and handling large volumes of data
A4Standard ISO paper size used for printable municipal documentsSWMRS

data.heading: Analysis Models
data.text: This section compiles or references key engineering artifacts, diagrams, and conceptual models that provide deeper context and validation for the requirements and architecture documented above.

children.heading: Use Case Diagram
children.text:
A comprehensive UML Use Case Diagram is provided, depicting:

  • The system boundary for SWMRS
  • All external actors (residents, workers, admins, supervisors, partners, sensors, APIs)
  • Major use cases (“Optimize Collection Route”, “Report Missed Pickup/Issue”, “Track Recycling Rewards”, “Confirm Pickup”, “Monitor Fleet Dashboard”, “Sensor Health Monitoring”, etc.)
  • Relationships (include, extend, generalization) are indicated per UML standard
  • Diagrams use a legend to clarify all symbols and connectors.
